objtitle.title: *Hecate, or The Night of Enitharmon's Joy*

objinfo.printdate: 1795The characteristics of the color printing indicate that this impression is the second one printed in 1795. The coloring on the printing matrix was restored before this impression was printed. The first impression in the 1795 printing session is *Hecate, or The Night of Enitharmon's Joy* in the Tate Collection (Butlin 316); the third impression of the design is in the National Gallery of Art, Edinburgh (Butlin 317).
objinfo.medium: planographic color printing with water color and pen and ink additions to the impression

provenance.name: Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery
provenance.note: Perhaps acquired by Blake's wife, Catherine, upon his death in 1827; perhaps acquired by Frederick Tatham upon Mrs. Blake's death in 1831; the dealer Joseph Hogarth, who offered the print, with the assistance of George Richmond, to John Ruskin c. 1843; at least briefly in Ruskin's possession, but probably returned to Hogarth; acquired c. 1878-80 by Arthur Burgess; J. W. Pease, probably no later than 1888; bequeathed by J. W. Pease to Miss S. H. Pease in 1901; bequeathed to Mrs. Valentine Dodgson in 1938; apparently by bequest to John Dodgson; sold Christie's, 21 Nov. 1952, lot 35 (£220.10s. to the dealer Frank T. Sabin); sold by Sabin to The Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery in 1954.

repository.institution: Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery
repository.collection: Henry E. Huntington Library and Art Gallery

desc.objtitle: Hecate, or The Night of Enitharmon's Joy, Object 1 (Butlin 318)

objnote.p: The title "Hecate" was first given to this work by William Michael Rossetti in his 1863 catalogue of Blake's pictorial works. Later interpreters identified the three human figures as the triple form of the classical moon goddess and witch, and further associated the image with the reference to "triple Hecat's team" in Shakespeare's *A Midsummer Night's Dream*, Act 5, scene 1. In 1990, the art historian Gert Schiff proposed a different textual source, Blake's own *Europe a Prophecy*, Plate 5, lines 1-9 (Erdman page 62). In Schiff's interpretation, the front-most figure is Enitharmon, a representative of mystery, fallen nature, and sexual repression in *Europe*. She separates and imprisons the youthful female (left) and male (right); her minions are creatures of the night (the owl and monstrous bats) or of ignorance (the ass and the lizard or toad). Schiff's title, "The Night of Enitharmon's Joy," is taken from a passage in *Europe* and has been generally accepted by Blake scholars.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Slightly to the right of the center, Enitharmon (or Hecate) sits with her legs drawn up to her chest and crossed, while looking to the left and slightly down. She appears to be nude except for the black gown draping her legs. Her left hand is holding a book open, while pointing to the book’s text. Two nude figures, perhaps a female (right of Enitharmon/Hecate) and a male (left) are behind Enitharmon. Only their side profiles are visible as they shield their faces away from the viewer. A donkey enters from the left and munches on some foliage in the lower left corner of the design. Behind the donkey is a rocky terrain. Nestled within the rocks is a peeking lizard (?) revealing only its head. Behind the lizard and farther up on the rocks, is an owl. In the distance on the right, an anthropomorphic bat flies above the heads of the three figures. Even farther in the distance along the right margin, an outline of another flying bat appears.

component.illusobjdesc: Hecate (or Enitharmon) is pictured sitting on the ground with her legs drawn up and her left leg crossed in front of her right. She appears to be wearing a dark gown or cloak that only covers her legs. Both knees are prominent and her feet are prominent at the gown’s hem; her shoulders and arms are bare. She has long hair and she looks to the left and slightly down, left eye lowered, while her left hand is touching an open book. Her left index finger points to the book’s text. Her arms are at her sides and her gown obscures her right hand.

A nude and youthful female (?) kneels to the left of Enitharmon (or Hecate). Only her right side, facing right, is visible; her face is behind the central figure's right shoulder and head. She has long hair that cascades over her right shoulder. Her right arm is beside and slightly behind her body, and her right leg is bent at the knee. Her right hand is pictured.

A partly obscured youthful and nude male (?) kneels or stands right of Enitharmon (or Hecate). He faces to the left with his head tilted down, and, although the side of his body is visible, his short (?), curly hair obscures his face. His left arm is at his side though slightly in front of his body. Except for his left thigh, his legs are not pictured.

An ass or donkey with large pointed ears, open mouth, and closed (or almost closed) right eye grazes in the left margin. Its head is bent down to eat the vegetation below it, and it stands, strides, or walks to the right with its right leg and hoof in front of its (somewhat obscured) left leg. Its head above the eye seems to be covered in fur or shaggy hair.
The rocky (?) terrain in the left side of the design may be a cliff, part of a hill, or part of a larger mountainous range that extends upwards.
The three human figures may be placed on a low mound, most clearly evident just right of the central figure. Apparently the legs of the figure on the right are behind this mound.

To the right of the donkey and mostly hidden within a crevice in the rocks, a lizard (or toad or serpent?) peeks out, revealing only its head, facing up and to the right. Its right eye may be raised upwards.
To the right of the donkey and above and to the left of the lizard, an owl perches in the rocky terrain and stares out at the viewer.

Above the three human figures, a hairy or furry-faced bat-winged creature flies or hovers overhead. Its large bat wings are fully extended. The fur on its head is spiky, and its expression suggests a threatening or angry attitude. Its nose, moustache, eyebrows, and beard give it an anthropomorphic appearance.
A second flying creature, possibly another fearsome bat or bat-like monster, is pictured between the right-most figure's head and the right margin of the design. Only its dark wings are pictured.
In the lower right corner is an opened book with blotted coloring that suggests an illegible text on the pages.
Much of the landscape appears to be covered with low-growing vegetation, perhaps including grasses, moss, and lichens.
The sky upper right and along the right margin is dark blue; this might be a night scene.
